text: Does this require a dynamic backend server when I select new dropdown boxes, or has it statically determined all the different combinations and simply fetches a static view of the different results based on what I have selected?

text: This is very cool.  I have a desire to create “status boards” for things like the Pkg server, but I have a disconnect between what I know how to do to create plots and graphs in a Pluto notebook, vs. what I have to do to get it hosted on a webpage.  Ideally, I would have some kind of tool that can “bake” the Pluto notebook (along with all of its graphs and whatnot) into a static webpage that I can serve at high performance.  But I am greedy, and I want to be able to use dropdown boxes and whatnot as well, if possible.  When I saw this, I wondered if maybe Pluto knew that there were only a discrete number of inputs, and so it precalculated all possible outputs and then stored them in a system where it could be statically served. Is that what the “statefiles” are?

Ideally, I would have some kind of tool that can “bake” the Pluto notebook (along with all of its graphs and whatnot) into a static webpage that I can serve at high performance.  But I am greedy, and I want to be able to use dropdown boxes and whatnot as well, if possible.  When I saw this, I wondered if maybe Pluto knew that there were only a discrete number of inputs, and so it precalculated all possible outputs and then stored them in a system where it could be statically served. Is that what the “statefiles” are?

text:
hey elliot! that use case is exactly what we’re going for — automatically turning any interactive notebook into a web page.

We don’t precompute results, but we do use the dependency graph to find out which bond values to send (together) and which outputs to persist. the coolest part is: these requests are stateless, and can be cached by the browser or by the network. we use cloudflare for the mit site, and all ‘popular’ slider values are cached by the CDN, our server handles cache misses, like the webcam input. So with the right cache setup, your server will only compute things once, when needed

elements.text: hey elliot! that use case is exactly what we’re going for — automatically turning any interactive notebook into a web page.

We don’t precompute results, but we do use the dependency graph to find out which bond values to send (together) and which outputs to persist. the coolest part is: these requests are stateless, and can be cached by the browser or by the network. we use cloudflare for the mit site, and all ‘popular’ slider values are cached by the CDN, our server handles cache misses, like the webcam input. So with the right cache setup, your server will only compute things once, when needed

text: (right now we’re working on the mit course as a trial run, but it’s definitely becoming something very cool! it can essentially turn any notebook into a rest api, completely automated :eyes:)
